bioprojects.title: Sanger Institute Tree of Life Programme: Data and Assemblies
Project Psyche - Lepidopteran Genomes for Europe

assembly_info.comments: The assembly ilAetPunc1.hap1.1 is based on 31x PacBio data and Arima2 Hi-C data generated by Project Psyche (https://www.projectpsyche.org/). The assembly process included the following sequence of steps: initial PacBio assembly generation with Hifiasm in Hi-C integrated assembly mode, and Hi-C based scaffolding with YaHS. The mitochondrial genome was assembled using MitoHiFi. Finally, each haplotype assembly was analysed and manually improved using TreeVal. Chromosome-scale scaffolds confirmed by the Hi-C data have been named in order of size. Chromosome Z was assigned by synteny to GCA_907269075.1

bioprojects.title: Carcharodus alceae (mallow skipper) genome assembly, ilCarAlce1 haplotype 1
Sanger Institute Tree of Life Programme: Data and Assemblies
Project Psyche - Lepidopteran Genomes for Europe

assembly_info.comments: The assembly ilCarAlce1.hap1.1 is based on 25x PacBio data and Arima2 Hi-C data generated by Project Psyche (https://www.projectpsyche.org/). The assembly process included the following sequence of steps: initial PacBio assembly generation with Hifiasm in Hi-C integrated assembly mode, and Hi-C based scaffolding with YaHS. The mitochondrial genome was assembled using MitoHiFi. Finally, each haplotype assembly was analysed and manually improved using TreeVal. Chromosome-scale scaffolds confirmed by the Hi-C data have been named in order of size. The Z sex chromosome was identified by homology with Thymelicus lineola / ilThyLine1.1 / GCA_963932265.1 and looks like a neoZ fusion of a Z and an autosome.

The mitochondrial genome was assembled using MitoHiFi. Finally, each haplotype assembly was analysed and manually improved using TreeVal. The exact order and orientation of the contigs on chromosome W (6,850 - 15,280 Kbp) are unknown.The exact order and orientation of the contigs on chromosome 1 (0 - 656 Kbp) are unknown.The exact order and orientation of the contigs on chromosome 23 (8,188 - 9,450 Kbp) are unknown.The Z chromosome was identified through read coverage and synteny analysis with Melitaea diamina (GCA_964264535.1).The W chromosome was identified through read coverage.

description.comment: Blood sample from adult female Heteronetta atricapilla (SampleID: SHBP4307). The black-headed duck is native to South America and is the only obligate brood parasite among the waterfowl (family Anatidae). This means that females do not build nests, incubate eggs or care for their offspring, but instead lay eggs in the nests of other bird species, which provide incubation of black-headed duck eggs. DNA source: Sylvan Heights Bird Park, Scotland Neck, NC, USA.

description.comment: The common big-eared bat (Micronycteris microtis) is a bat species from South and Central America. Recent research has demonstrated this bat's ability to find motionless food within clutter. Echolocating bats discriminate between background and prey based on glints or Doppler shifts in the echo induced by the (wing-)movements of the prey, but M. microtis can detect completely motionless prey (from Wikipedia entry). This sample of a male individual found in Orange Walk, Lamanai, Belize was procured by Nancy Simmons to generate a high-quality reference genome for Bat1K and the Bat Biology Foundation. Sequencing was conducted at Paratus Sciences and genome assembly was conducted at the Vertebrate Genome Lab (VGL) at the Rockefeller University, led by Erich D. Jarvis, Giulio Formenti, and Jennifer Balacco.

description.comment: Blood sample from adult female Nettapus auratus (SampleID: SHBP007). This project contributes to a broader effort to compare genome evolution in all seven brood parasitic clades among birds, and to test the prediction that the evolution of brood parasitism (and loss of parental care behavior) results in genome-wide signatures of molecular convergence and/or convergent changes in coding and/or regulatory regions associated with particular genetic pathways or functions. The focal species for this project is the brood parasitic black-headed duck (Hetronetta atricapilla), which is compared to representatives of three closely related genera: African pygmy goose (Nettapus auratus), ruddy duck (Oxyura jamaicensis), and freckled duck (Stictonetta naevosa). Contributed by the Brood Parasitic Bird Genomes Consortium.

bioprojects.title: Rhinoderma darwinii (Darwin's frog) genome, aRhiDar2, haplotype 1

attributes.name: collected_by
attributes.value: Lucas Vicuna, Anibal Velasco, Claudio Azat

biosample.collected_by: Lucas Vicuna, Anibal Velasco, Claudio Azat

description.comment: Darwin's frog (Rhinoderma darwinii) is a species of frog of the family Rhinodermatidae. It was first described by Charles Darwin during his voyage on HMS Beagle on a trip to Chile. In 1841, French zoologist Andre Marie Constant Dumeril and his assistant Gabriel Bibron described and named Darwin's frog. R. darwinii is currently classified as an endangered species by the International Union for Conservation of Nature (from Wikipedia entry). This sample of a larvae from a pregnant adult male was collected by Lucas Vicuna and Anibal Velasco at Reserva Nacional Villarica in Chile and dissected by Claudio Azat to generate a reference genome data for the Vertebrate Genomes Project (VGP). Sequencing and genome assembly were conducted at the Vertebrate Genome Lab (VGL) at the Rockefeller University, led by Erich D. Jarvis, Giulio Formenti, and Jennifer Balacco.

bioprojects.title: Spheniscus demersus (African penguin) genome, bSphDem1, haplotype 1

description.comment: The African penguin (Spheniscus demersus), also known as Cape penguin or South African penguin, is a species of penguin confined to southern African waters. It is the only penguin found in the Old World. Like all penguins, it is flightless, with a streamlined body and wings stiffened and flattened into flippers for a marine habitat (from Wikipedia entry). This sample was collected from a male individual at the Bronx Zoo in New York City and was coordinated by the Wildlife Conservation Society to generate a high-quality reference genome for the Vertebrate Genomes Project (VGP). Sequencing and genome assembly were conducted at the Vertebrate Genome Lab (VGL) at the Rockefeller University, led by Erich D. Jarvis, Giulio Formenti, and Jennifer Balacco.
